title.narrative: Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique

description.narrative: Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique

title.narrative: CONTRATAÇÃO DE FESCALIZAÇÃO RESIDENTE PARA AS OBRAS DE RECONSTRUÇÃO DO CANAL DE DRENAGEM E CONSTRUÇÃO DE 50 LATRINAS MELHORADAS NA COMUNIDADE DE PAQUITEQUETE, MUNICIPIO DE PEMBA, CABO DELGADO
ITB_001_2017_RECONSTRUCTION OF DRAINAGE CHANNEL AT PAQUITIQUETE NEIGHBORHOOD AND CONSTRUCTION OF 50 IMPROVED COMMUNITY TOILETS ? CABO DELGADO PROVINCE
Reconstruction of Drainage Channel At Paquetiquete neighborhood and Construction of 50 Improved Community Toilets ? Cabo Delgado Province

description.narrative: The project will tackle barriers in relation to weak inter-sectoral policy coordination and development, low institutional and individual capacity to plan for climate change, and financial constraints.
capital of a political entity
second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Creation of community resilience and livelihood

description.narrative: second-order administrative division
second-order administrative division

% of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender)
1. Capacity Perception Index
2. Number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimize exposure to climate variability
Adaptive capacity of coastal communities improved and coastal zone resilience to climate change enhanced.
1. % of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender)
2. % change in income generation in targeted area given existing and projected climate change.
3. % of population with access to improved flood and drought management, disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative:
National data and information relevant to coastal erosion and climate change risk management is currently very limited. Some climatic records focusing on a few weather parameters are held in government departments, but detailed records of more complex variables such as stream flow and sediment transport which can help development of a more robust CC risk profile of coastal zones are few in number.
Lack of data and poor management of physical coastal data presents a barrier to adequate monitoring and forecasting of the impacts of climate change on coastal zones. Responsibility for development and implementation of coastal land use planning legislation and relevant regulatory frameworks is also fragmented and duplicated across different sectors and government departments. Existing laws often are not applied or enforced. Decision-makers at national, sub-national and at local level are not informed and trained to extract/use environmental data and information, particularly that related to SLR and coastal erosion, to adjust municipal land use regulations and investment planning for CC coastal risk management. Access to mass media and other IT communication systems in rural areas is low, and illiteracy rates are high which pose a challenge to the dissemination of climate risk information. Average illiteracy level in Mozambique is about 56.7%, but much higher among women (71.2%). Furthermore, the most illiterate people live in the rural areas (INE, 2009). OUTCOME 1
OUTCOME 2: Baseline: Historical records from 1960-2005 point to a warming trend, particularly in central and north Mozambique of 1.1-1.6 ºC in maximum temperatures which can be significantly higher for the lowland coastal areas. In addition the analysis of these past records also indicates significant increases in duration of heat waves, as well as a delay in the start of the rainfall season. Furthermore to this, maximum temperatures are expected to increase by 2.5-3.0 ºC in the interior by 2040-2060.
Coas

50% of men and women in the selected project sites have declared ownership of adaptation processes.
50% of households in the pilot sites have increased their income by 50% (cumulative).
50% of households have improved flood and drought management (cumulative).

Target Achieved. Overall, 1,205 direct beneficiaries were involved in different project activities in the three pilot project sites (7 communities), and indirectly benefited 380 from the provision of temporary services such as procurement of local materials and labor for construction of some identified adaptation measures. Thus 1,585 individuals of which 54% women and 46% men is the total number of beneficiaries from adaptation measures.
Target Partially Achieved. Over 70% targeted beneficiaries benefited from Micro-finance services and products, mainly in Pemba and Sihane. Micro-finance failed in Pebane due to constraints with the Service Provider. Diverse livelihoods options were developed and still active in the 2 sites.
Target Partially Achieved. Flood protection implemented effectively in Pemba. Being finalized drainage system in Paquite community. Coastal erosion mapping exercise finalized, pending validation.
Project Final Evaluation and Closure.

description.narrative: To develop capacity of communities living in the coastal zone to manage climate change risks
of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: Coastal communities lack the resources or support to strengthen their resilience against CC induced hazards
At the end of the project 50 of men and women have declared ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender
Substantial progress has been made in regards to the Development Objectives At the moment 14 of men and 9 of women declare ownership of the adaptation processes

description.narrative: Adaptive capacity of coastal communities improved and coastal zone resilience to climate change enhanced

1 of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender
2 change in income generation in targeted area given existing and projected climate change
3 of population with access to improved flood and drought management disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative:
The VCA consultations during the PPG phase have shown that though aware of their vulnerability and that of the surrounding ecosystem farmers fishermen and all those whose livelihoods are affected by CC induced hazards at the district and community level have no financial resources and knowledge for resilience decision making in the face of droughts and floods
The coastal management expert report revealed that there is currently no protection measures being undertaken by communities against sea level rise and storm surges

At the end of the project 50 of men and women in the selected project sites have declared ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender
By the end of the project 50 of households in the pilot sites have increased their income by 50
50 of households have improved flood and drought management

Adaptation measures have been validated and prioritized at the community level and technical partners increasing ownership of adaptation process Community investment plans have been prepared submitted and approved by the Investment committee Access to finance and training Inhambane 5 demonstration fields in place SDAE working with same number of 1215 members group with 98 women 1 womens group 5 People trained and equipped for chicken production and received inkind loan chicks and food from FDM hired microfinance service provider for this project site 1 womens group organized and trained for swine production and building pigpen FDM This represents innovative production technology into low productivity agricultural and breeding practices For the other two project sites Cabo Delgado and Zambezia no activity reported for community training Microfinance institutions have been hired and started to work in all communities In Inharime Inhambane province FDM was contracted Diagnostic study realized Staff trained in saving and credit group methodology and 1 staff hired to work full time in Sihane community 6 savings and credit groups trained and active saved 64115 Mts 2 groups being prepared for inkind loans for chicken amp swine production All participants SCG Production groups receiving business training and financial education In Pemba Cabo Delgado province CCOM was contracted To date 20 credit officers were trained to work in the 3 communities and in their production areas out of town 3 service centers have been established A specialized institution hired by MFI to train its staff in the savings and credit group methodology Training ongoing with first groups to be formed by the end of July 2015 14 solidarity groups received loan 70 people for MZN 45500000 33 individuals loans provided 6 Women 18 for MZN 136 Million Total value of loans MZN 1815 Million of which 26500000 already paid back 5 ind 1 group All loans for small business petty trade that will contribute to households income All beneficiaries received training in business skills

description.narrative: Climate change risks to coastal zones integrated into key decisionmaking process and managed at community level as well as subnational and national government level
1 Capacity Perception Index

comment.narrative:
Capacity Assessment score 2455
The project will improve the capacity of local Govt to i to engage in stakeholder dialogue to understand needs and priorites for CCA ii the capacity to develop a climate risk problem analysis and create a vision and mandate for CCA initiatives iii to formulate policy and strategy on CCA initiatives 4 the capacity to budget manage and implement CCA initiatives
The scorecard uses 10 indicators deemed by stakeholders to be the most important capacity gaps
Capacity Assessment score 3835

Continued support has been provided to key government institutions at the subnational level in integration of CCA initiatives in their planning cycle These included key partnerships with the National Disaster Management Institute Municipality of Pemba District Authorities of Pebane and Inharrime National Meteorological Institute Agricultural Research Institute the Center for Sustainable Development Higher School of Marine Sciences Eduardo Mondlane University Marine Administration and the recently established Climate Change Knowledge Center at the Academy of Science of Mozambique Initial training in GIS and GPS usage and data collection have been undertaken in the three project sites Pemba Pebane and Zavora for development of CC risk mapsprofiles to further inform the planning system Climate information systems have been improved since project inception to support incorporation of CC risks into decisionmaking and planning

description.narrative: a) Number of necessary legal instruments on alternatives to imprisonment adopted; Number of prosecutors, judges and defense attorneys capacitated on alternatives to imprisonment by 2015; b) Number of UPR recommendations implemented and acted upon; number of training events on good functioning of the Palaces of Justice and their capacity to interact with community courts; c) Percentage of claims processed by the NHRC; Number of study sessions attended by comissioners and NHRC staff

comment.narrative: a) Draft law on alternatives to imprisonment approved by Council of Ministers and submitted to Parliament for approval. b)3 Palaces of Justice established in Morrumbene, Cheringoma and Moma; National Plan for the Protection of Human Rights approved. c) Law on National Human Rights Comission approved by Parliament; the selection process for members of the commission currently being carried out

- 88 staff members of the correctional services at central and provincial levels with trained on alternatives to imprisonment; - 50 Magistrates (judges and prosecutors) benefiting from workshops on alternatives to imprisonment. - 20% of UPR recommendations implemented - At least awareness raising events held and 2 TV spots broadcasted on human rights matters

- 587 staff of the correctional services trained on alternatives to imprisonment; - Over 50 Magistrates participated in workshops on alternatives to imprisonment - The target was not assessed, since there is a new UPR recommendation and the respective Action Plan has not being formulated - 4 TV spots and over 18000 leaflets on awareness raising campaigns on human rights and the rights of vulnerable groups
- II Cycle UPR Action Plan finalized - Study on Palaces of Justice carried out and validated Study on community justice carried out and validated

- II UPR Action plan has been formulated and approved - Study on Palaces of justice has been commissioned, carried out and validated - Study on community justice finalized and validated - Final project evaluation carried out - Resource mobilization for next UPR HR and CSO project achieved and project formulated

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of country diagnostics carried out to inform policy options on national response to globally agreed development agenda, including with analysis of sustainability and risk resilience

The project aims to build on the achievements of GHD, PEI & ACAFS. This joint project framework represents an effort by the UN to coordinate and enhance the synergies between various programmes aiming to support the Government to achieve UNDAF Outcome 3.
capital of a political entity

• PQG integrate P-ENR objectives and indicators • % annual budget allocations coded as environment or climate change expenditure • Level of use of environment and climate change budget coding across sectors • Number of districts with climate proof plans (Local Adaptation Plan (LAPs))

comment.narrative:
* PQG 2010 – 2014 integrate environment as a cross cutting issue with 6 main priority areas, as well as under Agriculture and Tourism priorities; Macroeconomic development priorities refer to the need to promote sustainable and inclusive growth and economic development
• 0.45% of the State Budget ( was on average coded as environmental expenditure 2007-2010[1] • Use of environment and CC function codes[2]: o MICOA institutions use 2 environment function codes (05511 – Research and Development Environmental Protection, and 05611 –Environmental protection n.e.c) o 2 sectors and to limited extent use environment function codes 0 LAPs

2.2% of State Budget. MITADER (alone – without including provincial DPTADERs nor tutelated institutions) uses 4 function codes (05321; 05411; 05511; 05611) in the 2016 budget and 2017 budget proposal; 22 institutions use function code 05 in their budget proposal for 2017, including FNDS, Ministry of Education and Technology and INGC (Niassa). Public funds linked to Climate change function code (05321) in 2014 was 25,378,000 Met (7 institutions) and in 2017 proposal is 47,168,000 Met (7 institutions) 3 LAPs elaborated

description.narrative: Human rights affairs

- Selected Indicator 1: Nº of Shadow reports produced and submitted in time to treaty and monitoring bodies of UN as well as the AUCHPR’s. - Selected Indicator 2: N. of complaints on HR violations reported. - Selected indicator 3: Nº of advocacy actions realized on ratification and domestication of relevant instruments. - Selected indicator 4: Nº of actions (advocacy and lobbying) in the formulation of legislation and policies that strengthen management and promote efficient use of public resources in line with HRBA. - Selected indicator 5: Nº of CSOs and CBOs engaged in the UPR Coalition Secretariat and platform. - Selected indicator 6: N. of CSOs Annual Human Rights reports on UPR recommendations publications
